results.title: How to innovate
results.creator_credit: Janet Isaac, Bruce Moir and Film Australia
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Innovations”.
One of three films for use in the process of educating teachers about the nature and benefits of innovation in the school. Contains a series of trigger items or vignettes separated by blank film to allow the projector to be stopped for discussion purposes. It is essential that these films be previewed to assess suitability for the audience and to enable preparation for discussion.

results.title: Protist physiology (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Examines the internal processes of independently living cells, including mechanisms for phagocytosis and digestion, and for saprozoic and autotrophic nutrition. Describes symbiotic associations between autotrophs and heterotrophs and methods of water balance.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Examines the internal processes of independently living cells, including mechanisms for phagocytosis and digestion, and for saprozoic and autotrophic nutrition. Describes symbiotic associations between autotrophs and heterotrophs and methods of water balance.

results.title: Protist ecology (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Discusses the vital role played by protists in the ecology of the planet Earth. Examines the commensal, parasitic, and mutualistic life styles practiced by a large number of protist species.

results.title: Planet earth: science in space
results.creator_credit: Louis de Rochemont Associates, United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Traces the development of space research; explains the need for satellites, rockets and other space probes; demonstrates how such tools operate; shows how their findings are reported; and discusses what they have contributed to our knowledge of space and of the solar system. Includes actual scenes of the assembly of instruments, the launching of satellites, and of the operation of tracking stations and computing centres.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Louis de Rochemont Associates, United States. National Aeronautics Space Administration and WGBH Educational Foundation

results.title: A New look at Leeuwenhoek's wee beasties
results.creator_credit: Bruce J. Russell and Biomedia Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of the Series “Inhabitants of the planet earth”
Examines free-living protists as viewed in natural time by differential interference cinemicrography. Discusses the classification and general characteristics of flagellates, amoebas, and ciliates.

results.title: The Flatworms (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce J. Russell and Modern Learning Aids
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Shows planarian’s moving and detecting food; the taking of food into the branched intestine through a muscular pharynx. One animal is shown regenerating new parts. The microscope reveals tapeworms in a catfish. A living scolex is shown clinging to the intestinal wall. Several proglottids are shown in detail.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Bruce J. Russell and Modern Learning Aids

results.title: Coelenterates (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Biomedia Associates and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Focuses on a hydra capturing a daphnia. Compares the reproduction methods of the hydra and obelia. Shows closeups of the physalia and limestone producing polyps in stony corals. Written and photographed by Bruce J. Russell.

results.title: Arthropods: millipedes, centipedes, crustaceans... (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Bruce J. Russell and Biomedia Associates
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Inhabitants of the Planet Earth”.
Of the eight animal species that of the arthropoda is the largest and biologically most successful. Using microphotography the film briefly but clearly explains various functions and activities of some members of the species. An up-close and personal look at millipedes, centipedes, crustaceans, arachnids and insects.
